thread.title: Ireland Baldwin bares her midriff in a blue plaid skirt
thread.title_full: Ireland Baldwin bares her midriff in a blue plaid skirt | Daily Mail Online

author: Sam Machado For Dailymail.com
title: Ireland Baldwin bares her midriff in a blue plaid skirt
text:
Ireland Baldwin partied it up on Saturday night.
The 21-year-old was spotted in West Hollywood, California after guest DJ-ing at The Peppermint Club in the big city.
She appeared to have a great night as she dressed up for her evening.
Party girl: Ireland Baldwin was spotted in West Hollywood, California on Saturday night after she was a guest DJ at The Peppermint Club
The model sported a long-sleeved black top that bared part of her stomach.
She added on a blue plaid skirt that covered part of her thighs as she walked down the sidewalk.
Ireland looked extra saucy with torn fishnet stockings on her legs along with a pair of white high top sneakers.
Stylish in plaid: The model sported a blue skirt with a black top and torn fishnets as she hung out with a male friend
Before getting into a car, Ireland took a moment to pose for the camera with a male friend dressed in black.
The daughter of Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger carried a grey bag with her that blended nicely with her ensemble.
As she let her dark blonde hair flow down, the young woman looked like she had a memorable night and went home to get some needed rest.
Long night: The 21-year-old headed home after her gig at the lounge
The Peppermint Club is known for its classy vibe with cocktails, party food and entertainment.
People can go in and enjoy themselves with friends in the lounge with drinks and music.
Ireland was seen heading into this bar last month.
Mother-daughter time: Ireland posted a rare Instagram selfie with her mom in July 2013
Ireland's parents were married from 1993-2002.
Last April, her mom Kim spoke to The Edit on the divorce and how difficult it was on her daughter especially with all of the attention it received.
'Divorce is hard on a kid, no matter how you cut it,' the actress said. 'And ours was very public and nasty.
'So I brought up Ireland in a very unconventional way. I just wanted her to be free. If she wanted to have her friends over and write over the walls with pen, that was fine. I wanted her childhood to be full of love and light and animals and friends.'
